posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: Hi when we run our code, the Spark Max flashes green, as expected because we set the speed to 0.5, but the CIM motors does not spin. Does this mean that there’s a software or hardware problem?

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Is the Sparkmax set to brushed? Is it wired properly?

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked:
yh it’s set to brushed. we’re pretty sure it’s wired correctly WIN_20240320_15_11_57_Pro 1214×1080 208 KB

WIN_20240320_15_11_57_Pro 1214×1080 208 KB

WIN_20240320_15_11_57_Pro 1214×1080 208 KB

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: Actually I’m not sure if we’ve configured it correctly. We used the rev hardware client, configured it to brushed and also had the green flashing, but we’re using PWM in code and PWMSparkMax doesn’t have a MotorType argument

posts.name: H
posts.cooked:
Right, PWM won’t have those features. I’d recommend isolating it to just the SparkMAX and motor side of things, just to check setup on those.

USB-C in to the SparkMAX and double check your config (don’t forget to hit save!) and try running the motor from REV client. If this works, your motor and sparkmax are good, and setup wiring wise is good (with the exception of the rio>spark connection, as this is not checked at this point).

If the previous step works, double check code and PWM cabling. I’ve not used PWM with a sparkmax, but is this similar to something you’ve had working before or is it new?
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Are two motor controllers connected to one motor?

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked:
We’re pretty sure we did the correct config: set CAN id, brushed, no sensor, clear sticky faults, and then burn flash. The result was the green flashes on the SparkMax but no movement from the motor.

We’re just starting with FRC and everything, trying to get our first command to work

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: What color does the SparkMax flash when when it’s not enabled? If it’s cyan or magenta, that means it’s in brushless mode. Blue or yellow, then it’s in brushed mode.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: No it’s just one sparkmax connected to the motor.

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: Yh the color is yellow so I think it’s in brushed mode.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: Has to motor been verified to work? Also check your PowerPole connection, you have to make sure they are fully seated.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.name: H
posts.cooked:
One more thing to try is measuring the output from the spark max with a multimeter. Or just swap it and try a different but identically configured spark max.

Commanding over USBC is my recommendation for this, as it eliminates one variable of the roborio.

We’ve seen 2 spark max failures this season where the status lights indicate a valid output, but the entire output side is totally dead. this has been with CAN /brushless, but the failure mode id guess affects both.

PS: changing can id should do nothing as you’re commanding over pwm.

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: Thanks everyone for the help. Turns out the problem was the PowerPole connections. Got the motors spinning for the first time
